description: From Middle English nillen, from Old English nyllan (“to not want”), corresponding to ne +‎ will. Cognate with Old Frisian nelle. Unrelated to Latin nolo which is constructed the same way, but the morphemes that compound both verbs are cognates.

verbs.description: nill (third-person singular simple present nills, present participle nilling, simple past and past participle nilled or (obsolete) nould)

entries.meaning: (modal auxiliary, obsolete) To be unwilling; will not (+ infinitive).

description: Compare Irish and Gaelic neul star, light. Compare nebula.

entries.meaning: Shining sparks thrown off from melted brass.
Scales of hot iron from the forge.

description: From Medieval Latin nil and nihil (“nothing”) to represent German nichts and nix (“nothing”), confused with Latin nix (“snow, snow-white thing”), used for white forms of zinc oxide. Doublet of nihil album.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Synonym of zinc oxide, particularly white forms used in medicine and cosmetics.
